coredata.dc:title: Picosecond geminate charge recombination: the dependence of reaction kinetics on initial pair separation
coredata.dc:creator: Scott, T.W.
Braun, C.L.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The recombination kinetics of geminate electron-cation pairs in liquid hexane depends on the photoionization wavelength used for charge pair creation. Pairs generated by two-photon ionization of anthracene with 355 nm light exhibit a first half-life for recombination of 108 ps at 191 K; 266 nm light, 930 ps. Longer recombination times are attributed to a greater electron thermalization length in the liquid. The initial pair is studied both by the temperature dependence of the escape probability and by kinetic calculations based on the Smoluchowski diffusion equation.

Pairs generated by two-photon ionization of anthracene with 355 nm light exhibit a first half-life for recombination of 108 ps at 191 K; 266 nm light, 930 ps. Longer recombination times are attributed to a greater electron thermalization length in the liquid. The initial pair is studied both by the temperature dependence of the escape probability and by kinetic calculations based on the Smoluchowski diffusion equation. 1. Introduction Photoionization in organic liquids often involves the formation of transient charge pairs. Each pair con- sists of a parent positive ion and its associated photo- electron. In non-polar liquids which solvate ionic spe- cies only weakly, these charge pairs are highly corre- lated by their mutual Coulomb attraction. The separa- tion probability is small and most pairs decay by geminate recombination. The influence of temperature and applied electric fields on the steady state recom- bination yield have been extensively studied and are well described by Onsager's solution to the Smoluchowski equation for a pair of diffusing charges. This model assumes that the recombination process involves mutual diffusion of the geminate electron and cation through a uniform dielectric medium under the influence of their Coulomb attraction. More recently, the time dependence of geminate charge pair recombination has been studied by both experimental and theoretical techniques. Pulsed elec- tron beam excitation has indicated that the lifetime of such pairs is less than 100 ps in liquid hexane [1]. 0 009-2614/86/S 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) Hong and Noolandi [2] have provided analytical so- lutions of the time dependent Onsager problem which predict a dramatic dependence of the reaction half-life on initial pair separation. A new kinetic technique based on optically stimulated charge pair dissociation has also been reported in which electron cation pairs in hexane were found to recombine with an initial half-life of 9 ps or less [3,4]. The work reported here deals with the application of stimulated dissociation in the study of charge recombination kinetics as a func- tion of initial pair separation. Direct kinetic measure- ments are found to support one of the basic assump- tions of the Onsager model, namely that the recom- bination reaction is in fact diffusion controlled. 2. Experimental Measurements of the geminate cation-electron re- combination reaction were performed using IR (1.064 Jum) stimulated dissociation of the charge pairs formed by picosecond photoionization of anthracene in liquid hexane. The light pulses were generated by an active 501 Volume 127, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 June 1986 passive mode-locked Nd : YAG laser and has a pulse duration of 35 ps. The UV pulses used for photoioni- zation consisted of 0.9 mJ at 355 nm or 2.0 mJ at 266 nm which, after passage along a variable length delay line, were combined with 20 mJ of the YAG fundamental. Both the UV and IR pulses were focused by a 100 cm focal length lens to a 0.3 cm waist be- tween the electrode gap of a conductivity cell. The liquid conductivity cell consisted of a 0.5 cm pathlength cuvette containing stainless steel electrodes separated by 0.3 cm and biased at 2 kV. Photocurrent pulses were amplified by a sensitive electrometer before entering a gated integrator synchronized to each laser event. The conductivity cell was electrically shield- ed by an aluminum enclosure. Measurements below room temperature were performed by purging the in- terior of the shield with a stream of cold nitrogen gas. Micromolar solutions of zone refined anthracene were prepared in liquid hexane which had been dried by storage over molecular sieves. All solutions were passed through a 0.2 ^on pore size Teflon filter. The experiments described here are concerned with the enhanced photoconductivity observed when both UV and IR pulses irradiate the solution compared to the conductivity caused by a UV pulse acting alone. To facilitate the rapid measurement of the degree of enhancement versus time delay, a laboratory minicom- puter was used to digitize the boxcar output, advance the optical delay line, operate electromechanical shut- ters and plot the decay curves shown in figs 1 and 2. 3. Results and discussion The mechanism of infrared-enhanced photogenera- tion has been discused previously [3,4]. Briefly, res- onant two-photon ionization of anthracene provides a source if cation electron pairs separated by a distan- ce typically on the order of 50 A. When only the UV pulse irradiated the sample, a small photocurrent is seen due to the fraction of geminate pairs which ther- mally surmount their Coulomb attraction and disso- ciate into free charge carriers. Typical thermal disso- ciation efficiencies are on the order of 0.1% at room temperature. When the UV pulse is followed in time by an intense IR pulse, an increased photoconduction signal is observed. Increases as large as a factor of 15 have been recorded. When only the IR pulse enters the cell, no photocurrent is observed. Following the work of Lukin, Tolmachev and Yakovlev [5] we as- sume that the absorption of light by the geminate electron is responsible for the enhanced photoconduc- tion signal. Excitation of a bound-to-free transition of the electron is thought to impart excess kinetic ener- gy which is dissipated in a second thermalization pro- cess. This secondary thermalization alters the electron- cation separation and on the whole increases the pair dissociation probability [3]. With this interpretation we note that IR enhancement will only be observed for correlated, i.e. geminate charge pairs. It should be emphasized, however, that the degree of IR enhanced conduction versus time delay between the UV and IR light pulses is not a direct measure of the geminate charge pair survival probability. Assuming a constant secondary thermalization length, we expect that the final escape probability will depend on the initial pair separation, thereby introducing a bias in the measure- ment of recombination kinetics [3]. The possibility of multiple-IR excitations of the geminate electron, as suggested by the supralinear IR intensity dependen- ce reported earlier [4], would enhance the sensitivity for small-radius pairs and make the measurement tech- nique less dependent on instantaneous pair separation. We are currently working to quantify this bias by comparing charge pair recombination kinetics mea- sured by both infrared photodissodation and transient absorption of the geminate electron. Until such a com- parison is complete, we have chosen to analyze exper- imental decay curves without making assumptions concerning the secondary thermalization process. Figs. 1 and 2 show the kinetics of IR-stimulated charge generation following two-photon ionization of anthracene using 355 and 266 nm light, respectively. The vertical axis is a plot of the difference in relative free charge yield when the UV pulse is accompanied by delayed IR excitation and when the UV pulse en- ters the sample alone. The first half-life for recombi- nation at 191 K is 108 ps at 355 nm and 930 ps at 266 nm. For diffusion-controlled reactions the slower decay at higher photon energies is attributed to a greater electron thermalization length in the liquid. The temperature-dependence studies described below support this point of view. The solid lines in figs. 1 and 2 give Hong and Noolandi's solutions [2] of the time-dependent Onsager problem with an assumed ini- tial distribution of electron cation separations.
